metadata.titleEn: Microscopic images dataset of heavy mineral grains from the Yarlung-Zangbo, Yangtze, and Pengqu rivers
metadata.description:
The identification of sand grains under polarized-light microscopy is an important and fundamental task in geological research. The accurate identification of sand grain types and the rapid acquisition of their content can provide important information on physical origin, tectonics, regional erosion, paleoclimate and paleoenvironment. Previously, the identification of sand grains required manual observation, which required specialist geological knowledge and a huge amount of work, and therefore had problems such as low accuracy, time consuming and subjective factors. In particular, there are still many challenges in working with microscopic image-based heavy mineral identification systems. For example, previous methods generally required manual feature extraction, which relied on the expert's knowledge of the geological field, and the feature extraction process was time-consuming and labour-intensive, making it a challenge to effectively automate feature extraction. The use of only orthogonal polarised images or only single polarised images cannot adequately capture the important features of heavy minerals and therefore cannot effectively differentiate between heavy mineral classes. Thirdly, previous methods generally default to the training and test sets having the same data distribution (i.e. independent homogeneous distribution), but in practice, microscopic images of heavy minerals often carry information from many source areas, which may not be related to the heavy mineral class, but are highly dependent on the sample acquisition source area and the imaging environment, which is reflected in the final image. The imaging environment is reflected in the fact that the quality of the final image can be affected by the production and filming habits of different staff, as well as the use of different microscopes, different camera systems and other instruments, which results in inconsistent data distribution between the training and test sets from different fields of origin, and it is also a challenge to train a recognition model with better generalisation. To address the above three challenges, this research proposes a new deep neural network-based heavy mineral recognition model: twin adversarial networks, with a primary focus on higher recognition accuracy and better generalisation to samples from new domains (emerging source regions or imaging environments).
As there is little research on automatic heavy mineral identification and a lack of published available heavy mineral identification datasets, it is particularly important to photograph and produce a dataset that can be used for heavy mineral identification from microscopic images in order to explore the feasibility of microscopic image-based heavy mineral identification.
The samples of dataset is collected from the Yarlung Zangbo River (16A063, N29°19′13.5 ″, E88°51′28.4″, Congsong in Xigaze)，the Pengqu River (16B027, N28 ° 09 ′ 35.96 ″, E87 ° 20 ′ 45.87 ″, Qudang in Tingri), the Yangtze River (16A001, N 32°10′0.02″, E118°58′ 41.61″; Qixia mountain in Nanjing). The 3546 polarized photomicrographs of 1773 grains were collected by polarized microscope Nikon LD1000 in the School of Earth Sciences and Engineering, Nanjing University. The dataset contains 12 kinds of heavy minerals, namely amphibole，apatite，biotite，epidote，garnet, monazite, muscovite, pyroxene, rutile, spinel, tourmaline, and zircon.
Based on three datasets of heavy mineral particle microscopy images from the Yarlung Tsangpo, Pengqu and Yangtze rivers, the samples can be stratified and sampled in a 7:3 ratio for each basin in a hybrid domain setting, and randomly divided into training and test sets. Training of classification algorithm models such as SVM, DT, RF, KNN, CART, VGG-16, ResNet34, SAN and automatic mineral identification tests were carried out on these datasets. A comprehensive comparison of all methods showed that deep learning methods significantly outperformed all traditional methods, while the new twin adversarial network scheme proposed in this study achieved the best overall results (84% accuracy, more than 10% higher than other traditional methods). The current study demonstrates that by effectively fusing the features of both polarised images through the structure of the twin network and removing domain-related information from the feature representation through adversarial training, the final model can effectively reduce the negative impact of domain characteristics on the recognition results, thus allowing for a model with better generalisation performance to unknown domains. Experimental results on real datasets validate the effectiveness of twin adversarial networks and their generalisation to unknown domains.
This dataset is one of the foundations for the automated identification and statistical development of heavy minerals, and our initial exploration not only demonstrates the value of this dataset, but also provide important lessons for future automated identification and machine learning of heavy minerals.
The paper related to this dataset has been published in: Huizhen Hao, Zhiwei Jiang, Shiping Ge, Cong Wang, Qing Gu, 2022, Siamese Adversarial Network for Image Classification of Heavy Mineral Grains. Computers & Geosciences, 159, 105016, doi: 10.1016/j.cageo.2021.105016.

background: Heavy minerals refer to the mineral components with high density (> 2.9 g/cm3) in siliciclastic sediments. Identifying the category of heavy minerals accurately is of great significance to the study of sedimentary petrology, which can supply a convenient and effective research method on sediments source-to-sink processing, transport path tracking, and locating potential economic deposits.
research objective: Here we propose the Siamese Adversarial Network (SAN) for image classification of the heavy mineral grains, which is the first time to focus on addressing the domain difference of heavy mineral images from different basins.
challenges: However, due to the variety and complexity of mineral images, the existing models are difficult to accurately recognize heavy mineral grains in microscopic images.
methods: In our research, heavy mineral grains collected from three different rivers were divided into three corresponding domains according to which river the grains collected from. Adversarial training was employed to eliminate the domain-related information of the three domains, so that the feature representation of the images only contains the distinguishing information of heavy mineral categories. The SFE receives two images of the same sample, and extracts features of the cross-polarized and plane-polarized heavy mineral images, respectively. The HMC identifies the category of the input sample through classifying the sample feature vector, whereas the DD receives those vectors as the input to identify the domain of the input sample.
dataset: The heavy mineral samples are collected from three different rivers, namely the Yangtze River, the Yarlung Zangbo River, and the PumQu River in the Tibetan plateau.
findings: The identification performance of the models under the three mixed domain experiments is consistently higher than the performance under the same domain settings respectively which shows that the model we proposed achieves a great generalization ability on unseen domains.

Concept Completion.Question: What are the challenges faced in the data collection process for heavy mineral grain classification using microscopic images?
What data collection method was employed to address the domain differences in heavy mineral images from different basins?
Where were the heavy mineral samples collected to develop a potential dataset for image classification?
Concept Completion.Answer: Yangtze River, Yarlung Zangbo River, PumQu River

Example.Question: Can you provide an example of a data collection method used to gather microscopic images of heavy mineral grains for automatic identification?
Example.Answer: A data collection method involves using a polarized microscope, such as the Nikon LD1000, to capture high-resolution images of heavy mineral grains. Samples are collected from different river basins like the Yangtze River, the Yarlung Zangbo River, and the PumQu River, and imaged under both cross-polarized and plane-polarized light to capture essential optical characteristics.

Example.Question: What is an example of a dataset used for training deep learning models for heavy mineral image classification?
Example.Answer: An example of a dataset is composed of 1773 samples of heavy mineral grains from the Yangtze River, Yarlung Zangbo River, and PumQu River, totaling 3546 microscopic images. This dataset includes 12 heavy mineral categories and utilizes images captured under both cross-polarized and plane-polarized conditions for comprehensive feature extraction.

Feature Specification.Question: What are the characteristics of the image data used for identifying heavy mineral grains in geological research?
Feature Specification.Answer: microscopic images, cross-polarized light, plane-polarized light, 12 categories of heavy minerals

Feature Specification.Question: What are the challenges in collecting and utilizing a dataset for heavy mineral identification, especially in terms of data distribution and domain differences?
Feature Specification.Answer: variation in image data distribution, domain differences, unrelated information from imaging conditions and sample collection methods

Quantification.Question: How many heavy mineral samples are included in a dataset for microscopic image classification?
What is the total number of microscopic images available in a dataset that includes both cross-polarized and plane-polarized images?
How many different heavy mineral categories are identified in a dataset using the proposed identification model?

Definition.Question: What does 'domain difference' mean in relation to heavy mineral image classification?
Definition.Answer: 'Domain difference' in relation to heavy mineral image classification refers to the variations and inconsistencies in image data that arise from different environmental conditions, such as different imaging equipment, imaging environments, or sample sources, which can impact the generalization ability of classification models across diverse datasets.

Comparison.Question: How do data collection methods for heavy mineral identification using polarized microscopy compare to traditional manual observation techniques in terms of accuracy and efficiency?
Comparison.Answer: Data collection methods using polarized microscopy for heavy mineral identification aim to automate feature extraction, which is traditionally done manually. This approach addresses challenges like low accuracy, time consumption, and subjectivity associated with manual observation. The use of deep learning models, such as Siamese Adversarial Network, has shown improved accuracy and efficiency over traditional methods by effectively capturing mineral features and generalizing across different domains.

Comparison.Question: In what ways do the challenges of feature extraction in automated heavy mineral identification differ when using single-polarized images versus cross-polarized images?
Comparison.Answer: The challenges of feature extraction in automated heavy mineral identification differ between single-polarized and cross-polarized images because single-polarized images may not adequately capture important optical characteristics of heavy minerals. Cross-polarized images, used in conjunction with single-polarized images, can provide complementary information that improves feature extraction and mineral classification accuracy. The integration of both image types helps overcome limitations associated with using only one type of image.

Comparison.Question: What is the difference in the generalization ability of heavy mineral classification models when trained on datasets from a single river basin versus mixed datasets from multiple river basins?
Comparison.Answer: The generalization ability of heavy mineral classification models is notably higher when trained on mixed datasets from multiple river basins compared to datasets from a single basin. Models trained on mixed datasets can better address domain differences and perform well on unseen domains by eliminating domain-related information and focusing on distinguishing mineral categories, leading to improved performance across diverse environments.

Interpretation.Question: How can the challenges of capturing heavy mineral features from different imaging environments be addressed to improve the accuracy of mineral identification?
Interpretation.Answer: The challenges can be addressed by using a deep learning approach, specifically a Siamese Adversarial Network, which focuses on effectively extracting features from polarized images and removing domain-specific information through adversarial training, thereby improving accuracy.

Interpretation.Question: What potential methods could be employed to ensure that the features extracted from heavy mineral images generalize well across different sediment source areas?
Interpretation.Answer: Adversarial training techniques can be utilized to eliminate domain-related information, ensuring that the features extracted are representative of the mineral categories themselves rather than the source area, thus enhancing generalization across different sediment sources.

Interpretation.Question: In what ways could the development of a comprehensive dataset of heavy mineral grains contribute to advancements in automated mineral identification systems?
Interpretation.Answer: A comprehensive dataset allows for training robust models that can automatically identify mineral categories by being exposed to diverse image characteristics and domain variations, thus fostering advancements in the accuracy and generalization of automated identification systems.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in accurately identifying heavy mineral grains in microscopic images from different river basins?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The difficulty arises from the variety and complexity of mineral images, which existing models find challenging to recognize accurately. Additionally, different optical characteristics displayed by samples under various lenses, and the influence of imaging environments, such as sample collection source and imaging conditions, contribute to the challenge.

Causal Antecedent.Question: Why is there a need for adversarial training in the image classification of heavy mineral grains from different basins?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Adversarial training is necessary to eliminate domain-related information from images collected from different river basins. This approach ensures that the feature representation of the images only contains distinguishing information of heavy mineral categories, thereby enhancing the model's generalization ability across different domains.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the lack of publicly available datasets for heavy mineral recognition in the field of geological research?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The lack of publicly available datasets is attributed to the limited focus on automatic recognition work for heavy minerals, which has led to a scarcity of such datasets. Additionally, the traditional reliance on expert manual observation for mineral identification, which is time-consuming and requires specialized geological knowledge, has hindered the development and sharing of comprehensive datasets.

Causal Consequence.Question: What outcomes might result from employing adversarial training techniques in the development of mineral classification models?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Employing adversarial training techniques can lead to models that effectively eliminate domain-related information, resulting in feature representations that are more focused on distinguishing heavy mineral categories. This can improve the model's generalization ability across different domains and enhance accuracy in identifying unseen mineral samples.

Causal Consequence.Question: How might the creation of a comprehensive heavy mineral image dataset impact future geological research and applications?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The creation of a comprehensive heavy mineral image dataset can significantly impact geological research by providing a foundational resource for automatic identification and statistical analysis of heavy minerals. It can facilitate advancements in machine learning applications for mineral recognition, aid in understanding sedimentary petrology, and support studies related to sediment source-to-sink processes, transport path tracking, and economic deposit location.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to develop a deep neural network model for the classification of heavy mineral grains under varying imaging conditions?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Developing a deep neural network model is important because traditional methods require manual feature extraction, which is labor-intensive and depends heavily on expert knowledge. The model focuses on improving recognition accuracy and generalization to new domains by effectively merging features from different polarized images and eliminating domain-specific information, thus overcoming challenges posed by different imaging conditions and domain discrepancies.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the significance of overcoming domain differences in datasets for heavy mineral image classification?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Overcoming domain differences is significant as it enhances the model's generalization ability, ensuring that it performs well on unseen domains, which is crucial for practical applications. This allows the model to be more robust and effective in real-world scenarios where imaging conditions, sample collection sites, and imaging equipment may vary, thus ensuring reliable identification of heavy mineral grains across different environments.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedures are followed to capture and prepare microscopic images of heavy mineral grains for classification purposes?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The procedures involve using a polarized microscope, specifically the Nikon LD1000, to capture high-level microscopic images of heavy mineral grains. These images include both cross-polarized and plane-polarized types to effectively capture the mineral characteristics. The samples are collected from specific locations along the Yangtze River, Yarlung Zangbo River, and PumQu River, and the dataset includes different mineral categories such as amphibole, zircon, and garnet.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can adversarial training be incorporated into the process of eliminating domain-related information from heavy mineral images?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Adversarial training is employed to remove domain-related information from images collected from different basins, ensuring that the feature representation of the images focuses solely on distinguishing heavy mineral categories. This involves training a Siamese Adversarial Network where domain-related features are minimized, enhancing the model's ability to generalize across different domains.

Enablement.Question: What technological advancements enable the effective combination of cross-polarized and plane-polarized images for mineral classification in geological studies?
Enablement.Answer: The use of deep learning models, such as the Siamese Adversarial Network (SAN), effectively combines cross-polarized and plane-polarized images by extracting distinct features from both types of images, which enhances the identification and classification of heavy mineral grains.

Enablement.Question: In what ways does the collection of mineral samples from diverse river basins enable the development of a robust dataset for testing classification models?
Enablement.Answer: Collecting mineral samples from diverse river basins, such as the Yangtze River, Yarlung Zangbo River, and PumQu River, provides varied data domains that challenge classification models to generalize their performance across different environmental conditions and source regions.

Expectation.Question: Why might it be expected that deep learning approaches outperform traditional classification methods in heavy mineral identification?
Expectation.Answer: Deep learning approaches, particularly those employing adversarial networks, can effectively integrate features from multiple polarized images and remove domain-related information, leading to improved generalization and accuracy compared to traditional methods that do not handle such complexities effectively.

Judgmental.Question: What are the potential challenges in collecting and preparing samples from different river basins for the purpose of creating a comprehensive dataset on heavy mineral grain images?
Judgmental.Answer: Challenges include ensuring consistent image quality despite variations in imaging environments, dealing with the influence of sample collection sources, and addressing discrepancies in data distribution due to different imaging techniques and equipment.

Judgmental.Question: In what ways could the integration of multiple polarized light images improve the accuracy of heavy mineral recognition, and what are the implications for future data collection protocols?
Judgmental.Answer: Integrating multiple polarized light images, like cross-polarized and plane-polarized images, captures more comprehensive mineral characteristics, leading to higher recognition accuracy. This suggests future data collection protocols should incorporate diverse imaging to enhance feature extraction and model performance.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze the effectiveness of various machine learning algorithms, including deep learning networks, in improving the accuracy and efficiency of heavy mineral identification from microscopic images.
Request/Directive.Answer: The research compared several algorithms such as SVM, DT, RF, KNN, CART, VGG-16, ResNet34, and SAN. Deep learning methods, particularly the Siamese Adversarial Network (SAN), significantly outperformed traditional methods, achieving an accuracy rate of 84%, which is more than 10% higher than other traditional methods. The SAN effectively integrates features from both cross-polarized and single-polarized images and uses adversarial training to reduce domain-specific information, enhancing the model's generalization ability.

Request/Directive.Question: Please propose potential strategies for expanding and refining datasets used for heavy mineral identification, considering the challenges of domain differences and imaging variations.
Request/Directive.Answer: To address domain differences and imaging variations, one could expand datasets by including more diverse samples from additional river basins or geographical locations. Incorporating augmented imaging techniques that simulate different environmental conditions could also help. Additionally, employing adaptive learning models that account for varying domain characteristics and integrating multi-source data could refine dataset robustness and improve model generalization.
